name: Domesday Book Manchester — Reconstruction (1086)
description: The Domesday Book (1086) records 'Mamecestre' in the Hundred of Salford: a church, a priest, land, and a mill. Scholarly reconstructions map what this tiny settlement looked like.
notes:
RESEARCH TARGET: Find scholarly reconstruction maps of Domesday Manchester.

Domesday entry for Manchester (1086):
Held by the king. Church of St Mary, 1 priest.
Land for a few ploughs. A mill.
Very small — possibly only 200-300 people.

Domesday Salford also recorded separately.

Possible sources:
- Open Domesday project: https://opendomesday.org/
- 'The Victoria County History of Lancashire' — detailed Domesday analysis
- 'A History of the County of Lancaster' (VCH Lancashire)
- Scholarly articles reconstructing Domesday geography
- Domesday Geography of Northern England by H.C. Darby

Manor held by: Roger de Poitou (initially), then Albert Greslet/Grelly.
Church of St Mary = site of present Manchester Cathedral.
Mill location unknown — possibly on the Irk or Irwell.
